headline: Chocolate Bourbon Pecan Pie
description: This chocolate bourbon pecan pie is a nice change from traditional pecan pie. Sweet chocolate chips and bourbon add depth to this classic Southern dessert.
name: Chocolate Bourbon Pecan Pie

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees F).
Heat sugar, corn syrup, and butter in a small saucepan over medium heat, stirring constantly, until butter melts and sugar dissolves. Remove from the heat and cool slightly, about 5 minutes.

Whisk eggs, bourbon, vanilla, and salt together in a large bowl until well combined. Slowly pour sugar mixture into egg mixture, whisking constantly. Stir in chocolate chips and pecans. Pour mixture into pie shell.
Bake in the preheated oven until set and golden, 50 to 55 minutes. Serve warm or chilled.

review.reviewBody: This is so good. I make it every year for Thanksgiving and Christmas
I like this best chilled and I do a generous pour on the bourbon bc I like the flavor. I line the crust with chocolate chips then pour the filling. Delicious

This is my 5th year of making this pie. I have to make an extra one because my daughter loves to take it home for herself! The only thing I do differently is use a chocolate Oreo pre-made pie filing. Yummy!

This pie is outrageously delicious! Everyone loved it on Thanksgiving. The only problem is, it actually takes at least an hour and a half or more to bake at 325 degrees. This recipe makes way too much filling for a 9 inch deep dish Marie Calender's recipe pie crust, and so, takes forever to bake, requiring constant checking to see if its done.

This is the most deeeeelicious pie I have ever made or eaten! Everyone LOVED it on Thanksgiving! And I mean, they couldn't stop raving about it. It was exactly what I expected when I wanted a chocolate bourbon pecan pie. The flavors of the bourbon and the chocolate are both spot on. I can't wait to make this again. Watch your cooking time with pecan pies though, they usually take a good 5 minutes longer than the stated time in the recipe. You can tell it's done if the outer half of the pie filling looks firm, but there's still a slight jiggle in the center when you take it out and wiggle it a little. It will finish cooking after you take it out. Good Luck!

I’ve used this recipe the last several years and it’s always a huge hit. I modify mine very slightly, using dark chocolate and caramel bourbon with a chocolate nut pie crust. Even when using the exact recipe to the letter, it ends up making two 9” pies rather than one.
Easy, rich, and very good! I may try some suggestions next time like reducing the chocolate or sugar just a bit, but we really love this pie! Will definitely make this for the holidays!
Excellent recipe! I’ve made chocolate pecan pies before but they usually have more of a brownie texture. This was more creamy and very good. I’ll be making it again soon.

Yummy, especially with vanilla ice cream. I made a few changes by using 4 tablespoons of bourbon, melting about a 1/2 cup of chips to mix in with the filling and also putting a single layer of chocolate chips on the bottom of the pie shell . I softened the chips in shell for 15 seconds in he microwave before adding the filling. After I poured the filling in to the pie shell, I also added a layer of pecans to make it look pretty. It took exactly an hour to bake. I covered loosely with foil when it started browning. When the hour was up, I turned off the oven and left the pie with door open to cool and continue to set in the middle. It was perfect!! Next time I may add another tablespoon of bourbon for more bourbon flavor.

This pie is delicious and was a big hit with the family this Christmas. I made a few changes—the biggest one was using a cup of agave nectar instead of the corn syrup (our grocery store was out of Karo) and it worked great. I also used 1/2 cup brown and 1/2 cup white sugar instead of all white, and I used two cups of coarsely chopped pecans. I used the full 1/4 of bourbon (just right) and put the 6 oz of chocolate chips in the bottom of the uncooked homemade pie crust before pouring in the pie filling that was just right for a deep dish pie. Served the pie with vanilla ice cream (to “cut the sweet” as they say in Steel Magnolias) and the leftovers were excellent too a couple days later. This recipe is definitely a keeper!

I made this for Christmas. I was a little short on Karo syrup so I added a tablespoon of maple syrup. The comments were "the best pecan pie ever "!
I'm making it again for New Year's day. I think I will add the maple syrup again.
followed the advice or others.....less bourbon and a little less sugar. Amazing!!

I loved it! It is enough filling for 2 deep dish pie crusts. When I baked it all in 1 deep dish crust, it took 65 min to set so I definitely recommend using 2 deep dish crusts. I also put a layer of chocolate chips on the bottom as another reviewer suggested. With everything else, I did exactly as the recipe says. Before this recipe, I made a chocolate chip pecan pie without bourbon every Christmas and it was good. But I’m not going back. Serve it à la mode!!
I loved the bourbon, just the right amount to taste it without being overwhelming. I did adjust a bit...halved the chocolate and increased the pecans. 4 stars because it was too sweet for my taste.
I've made this several times for Friendsgiving, and it's always a hit!
I layered the bottom of the filling with whole pecans and chocolate chips. I then poured on the filling.
Made this for Thanksgiving. Guests liked it--even those who are not pecan pie fans. I added some extra chocolate chips. Will make again.
A family favorite. I was short one egg so I added extra bourbon

Was easy to prep. It baked awesome. I had extra filling because I do not want the filling bubbling over. I poured the extra filling into small baking dish and baked it to appear like a Creme brûlée abd then I spooned it onto baked puff pastry ! Delish. Ok then I squeezed caramel chocolate onto it ;)

I’ve used this recipe for a couple years now and the only thing I did different this time was halve the amount of butter, the last couple years when I made it using the amount of butter in the recipe I noticed not always but sometimes the butter would overflow out of the crust, even using the deep dish pie crusts. This year didn’t have any issues with that so that’s how I’ll keep doing it. But everyone loves this pie when I make it! Took it to the work potluck last year and one of the guys ate probably half

Like the others, I put the chocolate chips directly on the pie shell before pouring the pecan mix in. Too much mix for one pie shell, not enough for two, started 1.5x the ingredients in the pecan mix and comes out perfect for 2 pies.
Oh my!!!! Normally I make pie and only have one piece. This is hands down the most flavourful pie I have ever had, so I had several pieces of this one it is my most requested pie that I make.

I slightly cool the heated mixture as stated and when adding to the egg mixture I got cooked egg. I may try making this recipe and do everything cold to see if I get a better result. The pie did taste good.
brilliant pie

I'd like to think I'm a pecan pie expert but sometimes that #$%@ doesn't work out. This one knocked it out the park! I didn't have any bourbon so I used cinnamon whiskey and it came out great. My usual pie's filling is on the wet side but this one is a lot drier. Seem a little chewier than my usual too. I will definitely make it again. I would include a pic but the site won't accept it so screw it!
I have made this recipe many times, and have always had rave reviews.
I made this almost exact to the recipe and it was fantastic. The only change I made was I cut the bourbon to 2 tbs. 4 seemed like a heck of a lot.

This recipe was easy to follow. I used a 9” glass pie dish and I attempted my own crust which came out too thick so it led to me having extra leftover over pie filling. I had some phyllo dough in the freezer so I experimented and put the phyllo dough in my small cupcake pan and poured the extra pie mix in there and baked it for about 15 minutes at the same temperature as this recipe. It turned out perfect!

This is the best. I dont use as much chocolate chips and I really let it cool before added them so they dont melt. I find using the full amount and letting them melt makes it too chocolatey so it use maybe 1/2 cup. I have this for my bday every year!
This is a very rich and scrumptious dessert! The only thing I changed was I only put 4 pecans in the centre rather than fill the entire top of the pie. I highly recommend this recipe!!!!

I made this for my future son-in-law when I found out that Pecan Pie is his favorite. I followed the suggestions of several other reviewers and put the chocolate chips in the bottom of the pie rather than mixing them in and I added about 1/2 cup extra pecans. It was delicious and really very easy to make. He LOVED it. Definitely will be making this again and again.

I made this for my future son-in-law when I found out that Pecan Pie is his favorite. I followed the suggestions of several other reviewers and put the chocolate chips in the bottom of the pie rather than mixing them in and I added about 1/2 cup extra pecans. It was delicious and really very easy to make. He LOVED it. Definitely will be making this again and again.
The family demands that I make this pie again. I had planned to use a slightly different recipe when I found this one which is much better, richer.

EXCELLENT EXCELLENT EXCELLENT!!! DELICIOUS AS WELL AND EVERYONE WHO HAD THIS WITH US LOVED IT!!!
THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU FOR SHARING!

Big hit at Christmas dinner. Was great as-is, but I’m also a huge bourbon fan. I think I’ll likely try it with 2T bourbon and maybe less chocolate next time but I have no qualms with how it came out as written.
Thank you
I didn't make any changes but I will the next time I will. It was to rich & chocolatey plus the bourbon was little overwhelming but if you like a rich pie then this will be right down your alley.
It was okay. It was eggier than the pecan pies I like. Not gooey sweet, it was more like flan with chocolate and pecans. Still good, but not what i was expecting.
no changes
This is my husband’s all time favorite pie. The only thing I do differently is layer the chips and pecans in the pie crust (to ensure equal distribution of deliciousness) and pour the filling on top.

changes: 3/4 c brown sugar instead of 1 c white, a heaping 1/2 c of chocolate chips instead of 6 oz --add most to a bottom layer of the pie, mix the rest w/ the pecans-- 1 1/3 c pecans instead of 1 c, add a smidge of cinnamon
I used one less egg based on another pecan pie recipe I have and more pecans. Delicious.
Made this with 3/4 cup sugar as advised by commenters, BUT definitely use the entire amount of bourbon. Use good bourbon too.
This pie has become a staple dessert for my family’s Thanksgiving!
This is the first pecan pie I’ve ever made and it’s delicious! I did only 1/4? cup mini chocolate chips and 3 tablespoons of bourbon. Definitely a keeper!
This is one of my favorite recipes for Thanksgiving. My family asks for it every year!

I have never made a pecan pie before and this one "takes the cake"!! Thank you for sharing this recipe. I did only use 1/4 cup or less of chocolate chips after reading reviews, and 3 tablespoons of bourbon to not overpower.

Much better if you cook the sugar-corn syrup-butter mix to a full rolling boil. Then let the filling cool to about 120° before slowly adding it to the egg mix. This greatly reduces the chance of ending up with a liquid or soupy filling.
Go deep dish crust, or you'll end up with too much filling for shell.
Blind bake the deep-dish crust for best results.
Substitute another alcohol for the bourbon. I've made it with rum, whiskey, spiced rum, and Grand Marnier with excellent results.
Add 1/4t of orange oil (thank you, King Arthur Flour!) for a really fun flavor – chocolate, pecans, and orange are made for each other.
bland

Surprised my husband with this today since chocolate pecan pie is his favorite. I made this according to the recipe ingredients however I melted the chocolate chips with the butter and sugar. I used a deep dish frozen pie shell and baked it first. Covered the edges with foil during baking as recommended by another reviewer. It was delicious! I didn't find the chocolate or bourbon to be overpowering and everything seemed well balanced. I will make it again for the holidays.
My husband LOVES it and is always asking for more.
I make this every thanksgiving.
It’s perfect with 3/4 c. sugar and 2 Tbsp. of bourbon. I didn’t mix in the pecans, just arranged them on top.
Excellent. Very rich.
I make this pie every year at Thanksgiving and Christmas and everyone always asks me to bring it again!
Yummy! It was the rave of Thanksgiving. I will make it again.
Wonderful !! Didn't change a thing.
Excellent Pie! This is just about the same recipe The Neally's have on the cooking channel! I Recommend this one "For Sure"! Two big Thumbs Up!

*I made this pie excluding the bourbon as some reviewers had said they left out. After picking out the recipe it was pointed out to me that the alcohol may pose a problem for some guests* My Thanksgiving guests were excited to try this pie but it fell short of their expectations. It was the very last of my pies to disappear after Thanksgiving.My pecan pie loving husband couldn't put his finger on what was wrong with the pie. I made the recipe as written and followed other reviews advice about placing chocolate chips in the crust. I did need to bake the pie longer than stated on the recipe to get it to set up.

Love this pie. As others note, cut the bourbon way back. If your not into the bourbon, the recipe works great without it with no changes needed to account for the liquid change. 2 tablespoons of bourbon seems to be a great compromise, as others have said.
I used maple flavored bourbon instead.
should be a hit!

I make this every year with one slight modification. Instead of putting bourbon in the egg mixture. I soak the pecans in the bourbon the night before. Never a bourbon taste to the pie, but it enhances the nuts! Very rich and decadent!
Benne /$ pence

The only thing I did differently was I used a full 1 1/2 cups of pecans and I divided the chocolate chips between the two frozen pie crusts (this makes two if you're using storebought) and I put them on the bottom instead of mixing them in. I also put some of the pecans in on the bottom and put the pecan/sugar/butter mixture on top of all of the chips & pecans. Baked on the middle rack and no need to shield the pie crust. Came out beautifully! EVERYONE loved them!!! People were going back for THIRDS!!

I made this pie with the adjustments that others recommended, such as 3/4 cup sugar and I just sprinkled about 2 ounces of chocolate chips on the bottom. I also made the crust from scratch in a deep bottomed pie plate. It looks lovely!

This might be the single best pie I have ever made. I went with a 10" crust and went 1.5 on the recipe without doing extra bourbon. I'm sure you could and it would be fine. Highly recommended and I'm stealing this recipe when I open my BBQ place some day.
I used Peachtree Distiller's Colorado Straight Bourbon and it was incredible. First dessert to disappear at the potluck.
I made this pie exactly as the recipe calls for and it came out perfectly!!!
A real crowd pleaser......I did add more bourbon!
This is excellent. I made it for the first time last Thanksgiving. Both my family and my in-laws loved it so much, they have all asked that I make it again this year.
Delicious! The contrast of textures - crunchy pecans and oooey gooey melty chocolate, combine with smooth bourbon make the perfect pie!
This is a an absolute favorite. I am going to try a diabetes friendly version this year. We'll see how it goes.

I used Kahlua or Jack Daniel's instead of Bourbon, and deep dish 9"pie plate precook pie crust put chocolates in pie plate
Dark chocolate chips 2 oz. on bottom rest in filling

I made this for our Kentucky Derby party and it was a hit. I do not like bourbon so I used amaretto instead. I served it with ice cream for anyone who wanted a scoop. I read other reviews and used a deep dish pie shell and there was still a little filling leftover. So next time a am going to get 2 regular pie shells and make to regular size pies.

I followed meowsie's suggestions and used 3/4 c sugar, less bourbon and less chocolate. I mixed the pecans and chocolate chips together and put them in the crust and then added the filling to it. Definitely use a deep dish and let the syrup mixture cool so that it doesn't melt the chips when you pour it in. Deep dish crust! Took it to ken and fritzi's housewarming and it was a big hit!
I used bittersweet chocolate spread in the bottom of the crust. Used the dark corn syrup and 1/ 4 cup brown sugar and 3/4 cup white sugar. I will be making this again.

Ive made this a few times now. People love it. I listened to all the reviews and followed their advice. This usually produces good results, but I find that the recipe as is, was just perfect. Except I just place the chips on the bottom instead of pre-melting.

Very delicious pie, but at nearly 650 calories per slice, it's very hard to find an occasion sufficiently grand enough to justify making this pie. I realize that's just a problem with pecan pies in general, but how good can a recipe really be if you can almost never make it?
Delicious

This recipe is amazing and I make it every Christmas to rave reviews - I usually add another 1/2 cup of pecans. This year however, I substituted healthier date syrup for the corn syrup. The taste was very dominant so I added another 1/2 cup alcohol (I use whiskey), 1/4 cup of cream, and one more egg. Was even better than the original and no more corn syrup :)

Made this exactly as the recipe stated and it turned out beautifully. I gave it four stars because it’s really rich! I think next, there will be a ‘next time’ for sure, I’ll cut back on white sugar. The bourbon can be tasted and it really melds well with the pecans. I might try a nut crust the next time.
I do a mix of dark chocolate chips and semi-sweet chocolate chips.
easy to make and delicious!

This is the family's favorite pie every year for over 10 years now. I've always made it just as written, but this year I cut back the bourbon just a smidge and used dark chocolate and they said it was even better!
No changes, and I'll make it again. Sorry, but it didn't last long enough to take a picture.

I found that this pie was FANTASTIC!!!
You have to like bourbon to appreciate this pie and since I'm a born & raised Louisville, Kentucky bourbon lover, I didn't find it to be too much!! I used Woodford Reserve Bourbon since that's one of my favorites. There was just a hint of bourbon flavor the day I made it, but after that it was more intense and delicious!!! 
Will definitely make again for my next Derby Party!!

I used Kahlua instead of bourbon as someone else suggested. I also used dark corn syrup and dark brown sugar. We all enjoyed it very much especially my husband. It is very rich and we just ate small servings.
Best chocolate pecan pie I have made. The bourbon addition was delicious.
Very nice pie. However, it was too rich for my husband and my 17 year old didn’t like the bourbon taste. So darn, guess I’ll have to eat the whole thing myself!

This pie was very good. I used a deep dish pie shell and it all fit in one shell. I didn't chop the pecans but arranged them prettily on the top. While this made a nice presentation, it didn't cut well. Next time, I'll chop the nuts. Overall - yum.

To die for! I made exactly as recipe stated for our Thanksgiving dinner and would not change a thing. We loved the additional 'kick' of both the chocolate and the bourbon. Eat in moderation - very rich, sweet and delicious!

Great recipe! I used a flaky crust recipe that makes 2 8" bottom crusts (2 c flour, 3/4c crisco and ICE cold water by the tablespoon flake w fork until combined) so I used 1.5 x the filling recipe and extra chocolate chips. Also did not pre cook crust before filling and baking.
I followed the recipe the first time. It was good. Then, I changed it up with Maple Crown Royal and caramel chips. OMG!!!Delicious!
Great but baking time was not long enough.

My first attempt making a pecan pie and the pie turned out very good only it was not the pecan pie I was aiming to make. If you follow this recipe you will have more than enough filling to make 1 pie. I ended up having enough filling left over to fill 6 small single serving crusts. Next time I may just make two pies or use a deep dish crust.
Another detail I want to point out is that the picture associated with this recipe shows pecan halves in the filling. The recipe calls for chopped pecans so where do the pecan halves come into play? Next time I will use a combination of chopped pecans and halves to make the filling.
I used a graham cracker crust which I would use again.
I only used 2TBS of whiskey, but next time I'd use more.
I added the chocolate chips to the warm syrup mix which worked out well. Most of the chocolate chips melted and result was a super chocolatey gooey filling. 
Can't wait to make it and eat it again.
Great recipe for a holiday traditional pie. Everyone loved the bourbon twist making an old recipe new again.

No doubt about it, If you like bourbon, chocolate and pecans, you will like this pie. Except for the crust sticking to the Pyrex pie plate (I believe this happened from poking to many holes in the dough), and the filling being runny, the taste was great. I believe I will make a few adjustments to the quantity of bourbon and poke only a few holes in the crust next time around.

Really delicious pie. A good bourbon will do you well. Don't skimp and go cheap. Served with a dollop of fresh whip cream. Never knew how much I like bourbon until I made this pie. Followed recipe, had no problems whatsoever.
